So the whole idea tricks people by superimposing their common perception over the top of something that is impossible to test because of the speeds involved. People think of light as a beam they can see side on because they think of a flashlight which hits dust particles in the air, but in such case they are actually seeing light coming in a straight line from various dust particles to their eyes: they are NOT seeing the actual original light, but are seeing deflected light. @mathewmunro3770  It's not so much about the rate that time "flies by". It's more about the length of the worldline between two events in spacetime. That length is the proper time of the worldline (ie the time experienced by someone on the worldline).  Because spacetime geometry is hyperbolic in nature, our intuitions about what the "shortest" path between two events in spacetime doesn't work. The shortest path will actually tend to look like the longer one in normal cartesian coordinates. The longest path between two events in spacetime (assuming they are time-like separated) is always a straight line. Any other path will be shorter. So, the twin that stays behind on Earth has a straight line path between the departure and return of his brother, so he experiences the most possible time between those two events. His brother, taking a shorter path through spacetime between those two events; a feat that requires accelerating somewhere along the journey; will be younger upon his return as a result.  If both brothers accelerate but in a non-equal way, then you have to look at their worldlines and do the math to determine the length of each to figure out which one is older upon their reuniting, or if they're the same age.

This is essentially the famous pole-vaulter running through a barn problem, so I'll use that analogy as it is more fun.  Alice is carrying a long pole through a barn with doors on each end.  At rest, the pole is too long to fit into the barn with both doors closed.  Alice, understanding special relativity, makes a bet with her friends Bob and Charlie that, if she can run fast enough, she can fit the pole inside the barn with both doors closed.  She arranges to have Bob close the front doors as soon as the end of the pole passes into the barn, and Charlie to open the back doors just before the front of the pole reaches the end of the barn.                                                         A                              _____________                                            /                           \            O                            /                             \ ____/ |\________         B (front door)      C (back door)            /\                            _______________     So, with the front doors initially open and the back doors initially closed, Alice runs with her pole through the barn, and Bob and Charlie both handle their door opening/closing duties.  Is the pole ever completely inside the barn with both doors closed at the same time?   Let's first consider Bob and Charlie's perspective.  Since they occupy the same inertial reference frame (they are motionless relative to each other), I'll just say from Bob's perspective. So from Bob's perspective, the pole shrinks due to length contraction.  Assuming Alice runs fast enough, Bob will see the pole shrink so much that it becomes shorter than the barn.  So when he closes the front doors, the front of the pole will not yet have reached the back doors, hence Charlie will not yet have opened them.  Therefore, according to Bob, the pole fits inside the barn with both doors closed.  But now let's consider Alice's perspective.  According to Alice, the pole stays the same length it has always been. In fact, it is the barn that shrinks.  Clearly if the pole didn't fit into the barn at rest, it certainly won't fit into it now that the barn is shorter.  Therefore, the front of the pole will reach the back of the barn long before the back of the pole clears the front doors.  So Alice will say that Charlie opened the back doors before Bob closed the front doors, and the pole never fit inside the barn with both doors closed.    How can this be? Relativity tells us that both points of view are equally valid.  The problem is with simultaneity.  Because of time dilation, two observers in different inertial frames travelling at some non-zero relative velocity will disagree on when some event happens.  In our example here, Bob and Alice will disagree on when Charlie opens the back doors.  Bob will say that Charlie opened the doors after Bob closed the front doors, but Alice will say that Charlie opened the back doors before Bob closed the front doors.

This video presents incorrect (or at best confusing) equations for time dilation and length contraction.  TIME-DILATION EQUATION  First, you can write the time-dilation equation several different ways, all of which are equivalent. Because people often get confused over who T is and who T naught is (or who T1 is and who T2 is), I like to use descriptive words. One way to write the equation is T for proper-time person = T for other person TIMES the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] ). An equivalent way to write it is T for other person = T for proper-time person TIMES (1 DIVIDED BY the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] ) ), which is the same as T for other person = T for proper-time person TIMES gamma, where gamma equals 1 DIVIDED BY the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] ). It’s much easier to express this in math symbols than words, but I can’t do it in these comments.   Let’s use the first equation: T for proper-time person = T for other person TIMES the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] ).   Second, one must correctly identify who is the “proper-time person” and who is the “other person.” Proper time is the time duration (interval) between events in the reference frame where the events happen at the same place. The two events are the start of the time interval (Event 1), and the second event is the end of the time interval (Event 2). The person who measures proper time measures the two events at the same place, using a watch on his or her wrist. That’s why many people call proper time “wristwatch” time.   Third, in example in the video, you are standing at the train station and Bob is on the train. As measured by you, Bob is measuring proper time because he measures the time duration (interval) between events in the reference frame where the events happen at the same place: the start of the time interval (Event 1) and the end of the time interval (Event 2). Bob uses the same clock (the watch on his wrist) to measure Events 1 and 2, and therefore Bob measures proper time. For Bob, both events happen at the same place; Bob measures both events by looking at the watch on his wrist. (From your reference frame, with you on the platform, the events happen at different places.)   From your frame of reference, the time-dilation equation is   T for proper-time person = T for other person TIMES the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] ).  Substituting the names of the observers, we get the following:   T for Bob = T for you TIMES the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] ).  You could also rearrange the terms to get the following:  T for you = T for Bob TIMES (1 DIVIDED BY the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] ) ), which is the same as T for you = T for Bob TIMES gamma, where gamma equals 1 DIVIDED BY the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] ).  LENGTH-CONTRACTION EQUATION  First, you can write the length-contraction dilation equation several different ways, all of which are equivalent. Because people often get confused over who is measuring L and L naught (or who L1 is and who L2 is), I like to use descriptive words. Let’s use “L rest” for the person measuring the “rest length” of the object and “L contracted” for the person measuring the contracted length of the object. (Note: Length contraction only occurs in the direction of motion.)  One way to write the length-contraction equation is L contracted = L rest TIMES the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] ). An equivalent way to write it is L rest = L contracted TIMES (1 DIVIDED BY the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] ) ), which is the same as L rest = L contracted TIMES gamma, where gamma equals 1 DIVIDED BY the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] ). It’s much easier to express this in math symbols than words, but I can’t do it in these comments.   Let’s use the first equation: L contracted = L rest TIMES the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] )  Second, one must correctly identify who is measuring rest length and who is measuring contracted length. Rest length is the length of an object in the reference frame where the object is at rest. Contracted length is the length of an object in the reference frame where the object is not at rest (i.e., it’s moving). In the video, the observers are measuring the length of the train. The train is at rest in Bob’s reference frame—the train is not moving relative to Bob—so he is measuring the rest-length of the train. In your reference frame (with you standing in the station), the train is moving, so you are measuring the contracted length of the train.   From your frame of reference, the length-contraction equation is   L contracted = L rest TIMES the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] )  Substituting the names of the observers, we get the following:   L as measured by you = L as measured by Bob TIMES the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] )  You could also rearrange the terms to get the following:  L as measured by Bob = L as measured by you TIMES (1 DIVIDED BY the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] ) ), which is the same as L as measured by Bob = L as measured by you TIMES gamma, where gamma equals 1 DIVIDED BY the SQUARE ROOT of (1 MINUS [v squared / c squared] ).

Imagine this scenario: Alice and Bob are each in spaceships that are drifting towards each other. Charlie is in another spaceship off to the side watching Alice and Bob.  A ----->  <------- B           C  The velocity of any of the three spaceships depends on what reference frame it is being measured from.  For instance, from Alice's frame of reference, Alice is stationary. From Charlie's point of view, Alice is travelling directly towards Bob.  Let's suppose that Charlie measures the velocities of both Alice and Bob and finds them each to be travelling towards each other at 51% of the speed of light. This is perfectly valid since neither is travelling at or faster than the speed of light.  Now let's move into Alice's point of view.  She is stationary while Bob is moving towards her.  In special relativity, when moving between frames, we do not simply add velocities in the same way we do in Newtonian kinematics as that would violate the rule that nothing can travel faster than the speed of light.  It is not true that Bob is travelling towards Alice at 102% of the speed of light.  The requirement that nothing travel faster than light forces us to move between reference frames through what's called a "Lorentz transformation" rather than by the classical "Galilean transformation" that simply adds/subtracts the velocities.  These are just different formulas for changing coordinates from one reference frame to another so that the postulate that nothing travels faster than light speed is not violated.  So special relativity tells us that Alice will measure Bob's velocity as less than the speed of light.

There is another pretty important aspect of length contraction that this video didn't cover. Say there is another train stop 1 light year down the track from you. From Bob's point of view on the train, the distance to that next train stop is shorter than 1 light year. So from your point of view the length of the train is contracted, but from Bob's point of view the distance ahead of him is contracted. This is important because you and Bob have to agree on one other thing besides the speed of light: how many ticks of a clock separate two events. The example of Bob looking in the mirror is an instance of a light clock, so lets keep using that. You see time moving slower for Bob because the light has to travel a longer distance going back and forth. However, if you could watch his entire journey to the next train stop, you could count the number of back and forth "ticks" of the light clock going back and forth between Bob and the mirror. Lets say you count X ticks. Now for Bob that light is traveling a much shorter path back and forth. If the distance to the next train stop was 1 light year, he would expect to count Y ticks, where Y > X. But when you meet up at the train stop to compare notes, you must agree on how many ticks of the clock there were, Bob must also have seen X ticks. This means Bob could not have traveled 1 light year from his perspective. I am pretty sure from Bob's perspective the distance to the next train station is 0.866 light-years (his forward length contraction is proportional to how much you see time slowed for him, if you see his clocks running at 0.866 times the speed of yours, he only has to cover 0.866 times the distance you perceive to achieve the same number of ticks).  edit: Note that you might think this contradicts the relativity of simultaneity discussed in the video. It doesn't, because that principle is only about things that don't have a cause and effect relationship. The timing between the two lightning strikes can be disagreed about because neither could have caused the other, but the light clock setup with the mirror is a series of cause-and-effect relationships which you must agree on. Proper time/length is measured by the frame of reference that conducts the initial and final measurement in the same spatial coordinates relative to that reference frame.  For example, when the flashlight is shone on the mirror and back, the train observer starts and stops the stopwatch at the same spatial coordinates relative to the mirror (since he is standing still on the train) therefore he measures proper time. The observer at the station however, starts the stopwatch when the mirror is behind the station, and stops the stopwatch when the mirror is now closer to the station. This means the measurement of initial and final time occurred in different spatial coordinates for the station observer, therefore her time dilates and she measures a larger time.  Same for the length. The front and back of the train are always located in the same spatial coordinates relative to the train observer no matter how fast the train is moving,  so the train measures proper length. The station observer however will always measure the front and back of the train at different spatial coordinates because the train is constantly moving - each measurement of length will occur at different points in space.
